brief_summary.textblock:
Sedation is often needed for young children undergoing minor procedures in the emergency
      department (ED). Oral midazolam is one of the most commonly used regimens for children
      undergoing laceration repair but its sedative efficacy was shown to be suboptimal. In only
      one randomized controlled study oral ketamine has been used successfully for procedural
      sedation for laceration repair. A recent study showed that the combination of oral midazolam
      and oral ketamine provided deeper sedation compared with oral midazolam alone. However
      children treated wuth the combination of midazolam and ketamine required longer recovery

      Hypothesis:

      Oral ketamine can provide superior sedation to oral midazolam in children requiring sedation
      for laceration repair.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Randomized, Clinical Trial of Oral Midazolam Versus Oral Ketamine for Sedation During Laceration Repair.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        • Any child with laceration requiring sedation

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Major trauma

          -  Closed head injury associated with loss of consciousness

          -  Abnormal neurologic examination in a previously normal child

          -  Significant developmental delay or baseline neurological deficit

          -  A patient with seizures

          -  Elevated intra-cranial pressure

          -  Hypersensitivity to midazolam or ketamine

          -  Hypertension

          -  Hyperthyroidism or a patient receiving thyroid replacement

          -  alcohol intoxication or a history of alcohol abuse

          -  Acute or chronic respiratory, cardiac, renal or hepatic abnormalities

          -  Glaucoma

          -  Known psychiatric disease

          -  American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score of more than 2

          -  Informed consent cannot be obtained from legal guardian

clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Clinical Trial of Oral Midazolam Versus Oral Ketamine for Sedation During Laceration Repair.

primary_outcome.description: A parent will assess the child's pain on a Visual analog scale
primary_outcome.measure: Pain score: Visual analog score (VAS)- by a parent
primary_outcome.time_frame: During the procedure - up to 1 hour

primary_outcome.description: patients who fail to achieve University of Michigan Sedation Scale (UMSS) of two or higher will be switched to IV sedation
primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients requiring IV sedation
primary_outcome.time_frame: During the procedure - up to 1 hour

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the procedure - up to 1 hour
During the procedure  - up to 1 hour
During the procedure - up to 1 hour

secondary_outcome.measure: • Time from procedure to full recovery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: While in the ED - estimated time around 2 hours

secondary_outcome.description:
Significant adverse effects are defined as
Oxygen desaturation <92% or hypoventilation requiering ventilatory support
Need for hemodynamic support
Anaphylaxis
Seizures
Any adverse effects requiring patient admission
secondary_outcome.measure: The occurrence of adverse effects during the ED stay
secondary_outcome.time_frame: While in the ED - estimated time around 2 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: • Patients and parents satisfaction assessed on VAS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: While in the ED - estimated time around 2 hours
